title: Banda Sea
text:
The Banda Sea () is a <a href="sea">sea</a> in the <a href="Maluku%20Islands">Maluku Islands</a> of <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, connected to the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> but surrounded by hundreds of islands, as well as the <a href="Halmahera%20Sea">Halmahera</a> and <a href="Ceram%20Sea">Ceram Sea</a>s. It is about 1000 km (600 mi) east to west, and about 500 km (300 mi) north to south.
Extent.
The <a href="International%20Hydrographic%20Organization">International Hydrographic Organization</a> (IHO) defines the Banda Sea as being one of the waters of the <a href="East%20Indian%20Archipelago">East Indian Archipelago</a>. The IHO defines its limits as follows:
"On the North" The Southern limits of the <a href="Molucca%20Sea">Molukka Sea</a> and the Western and Southern limits of the <a href="Ceram%20Sea">Ceram Sea</a>.
"On the East." From Tg Borang, the Northern point of Noehoe Tjoet [<a href="Kai%20Besar">Kai Besar</a>], through this island to its Southern point, thence a line to the Northeast point of Fordata, through this island and across to the Northeast point of Larat, <a href="Tanimbar%20Islands">Tanimbar Islands</a> (), down the East coast of Jamdena [<a href="Yamdena">Yamdena</a>] Island to its Southern point, thence through Anggarmasa to the North point of Selaroe and through this island to Tg Aro Oesoe its Southern point ().
"On the South." A line from Tanjong Aro Oesoe, through Sermata to Tanjong Njadora the Southeast point of Lakov [Lakor, "sic"] () along the South coasts of <a href="Leti%20Islands">Lakov [Lakor], Moa and Leti Islands</a> to Tanjong Toet Pateh, the West point of Leti, thence a line to Tanjong Sewirawa the Eastern extremity of <a href="Timor">Timor</a> and along the North coast as far as <a href="125th%20meridian%20east">longitude 125° East</a>.
"On the West." From a point on the North coast of Timor in 125° East up this meridian to <a href="Alor%20Island">Alor Island</a>, thence round the East point and along the North coasts of the Alor, <a href="Pantar">Pantar</a>, <a href="Lembata">Lomblen</a> and <a href="Adonara">Adoenara</a> Islands and thence across the Northern end of Flores Strait to Tanjong Serbete the Eastern extreme of <a href="Flores">Flores</a>, thence a line from its Northern point () to Kalaotoa Island () and through the chain of islands lying between it and the South point of <a href="Selayar%20Island">Pulo Salayar</a>, through this island and across the Strait to Tanjong Lassa, <a href="Sulawesi">Celebes</a> (), thence along the Southern limit of the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Boni">Gulf of Boni</a> and up the East coast of Celebes to Tanjong Botok ().
Geography.
Islands bordering the Banda Sea include <a href="Sulawesi">Sulawesi</a> to the west, <a href="Buru">Buru</a>, <a href="Ambon%20Island">Ambon Island</a>, <a href="Seram%20Island">Seram</a>, <a href="Aru%20Islands%20Regency">Aru Islands</a>, <a href="Barat%20Daya%20Islands">Barat Daya Islands</a>, to the <a href="Tanimbar%20Islands">Tanimbar Islands</a>, the <a href="Kai%20Islands">Kai Islands</a> and <a href="Timor">Timor</a> in the East. Although the borders of the sea are hazardous to <a href="navigation">navigation</a>, with many small rocky islands, the middle of the sea is relatively open. Island groups within the sea include the <a href="Banda%20Islands">Banda Islands</a>. A number of islands in the Banda Sea are active volcanoes including Gunung Api and Manuk in the Banda Islands.
Geology.
Plate tectonic activities in Banda Sea.
The Banda arc is famous for its 180° curvature and is, in Timor, generally agreed to be the product of collision between a volcanic arc and the Australian continental margin. The Banda Sea occupies the main portion of the <a href="Banda%20Sea%20Plate">Banda Sea Plate</a>. The southern margin of the sea consists of <a href="island%20arc">island arc</a>s above <a href="subduction%20zone">subduction zone</a>s. To the east of the <a href="Sunda%20Trench">Sunda Trench</a> is the <a href="Timor%20Trough">Timor Trough</a> which lies south of <a href="Timor">Timor</a>, the Tanimbar Trough south of the <a href="Tanimbar%20Islands">Tanimbar Islands</a> and the <a href="Aru%20Trough">Aru Trough</a> east of the <a href="Aru%20Islands%20Regency">Aru Islands</a>. These trenches are the subduction zone of the <a href="Indo-Australian%20plate">Indo-Australian plate</a> beneath the Banda Sea Plate, where the Indo-Australian Plate moves northwards. Fore-arc sediments progressively carried northwards by the Indo-Australian Plate have been folded and faulted forming Timor island. To the northeast lies <a href="Seram">Seram Island</a> which overlies the subduction of the <a href="Bird%27s%20Head%20Plate">Bird's Head Plate</a> of <a href="West%20Papua%20%28province%29">West Papua</a>. The deepest point of the sea, <a href="Weber%20Deep">Weber Deep</a>, is an exposed oceanic fault and the world's deepest <a href="forearc">forearc</a> basin, with depth more than .
Earthquakes.
Earthquakes are very frequent in the area, due to the confluence of three tectonic plates - Eurasian, Pacific and Indo-Australian plates.
Ecology.
The Banda Sea is a <a href="marine%20ecoregion">marine ecoregion</a>, as defined by the <a href="World%20Wildlife%20Fund">World Wildlife Fund</a>. It is part of the <a href="Coral%20Triangle">Coral Triangle</a> region, which has the greatest diversity of coral reef species in the broader <a href="Indo-Pacific">Indo-Pacific</a>.
The islands surrounding the Banda Sea are part of <a href="Wallacea">Wallacea</a>, a biogeographical region that contains the islands lying between Asia and Australia which haven't been joined to either continent. The islands of Wallacea are home to a mix of plant and animal species from both tropical <a href="Asia">Asia</a> (the <a href="Indomalayan%20realm">Indomalayan realm</a>) and the <a href="Australasian%20realm">Australasian realm</a> which includes Australia and New Guinea.
The islands are divided among several <a href="terrestrial%20ecoregion">terrestrial ecoregion</a>s. The northern islands of <a href="Sulawesi%20lowland%20rain%20forests">Sulawesi</a>, <a href="Buru%20rain%20forests">Buru</a>, and <a href="Seram%20rain%20forests">Seram</a> constitute separate <a href="tropical%20and%20subtropical%20moist%20broadleaf%20forests">tropical moist forest</a> ecoregions. The islands south of the Banda Sea are among the driest in Indonesia, and are home to <a href="tropical%20and%20subtropical%20dry%20broadleaf%20forests">tropical dry forests</a>. The <a href="Timor%20and%20Wetar%20deciduous%20forests">Timor and Wetar deciduous forests</a> ecoregion includes Timor and Wetar. The Lesser Sunda Islands from <a href="Alor%20Island">Alor</a> through <a href="Flores">Flores</a> and <a href="Sumbawa">Sumbawa</a> to <a href="Lombok">Lombok</a> constitute the <a href="Lesser%20Sundas%20deciduous%20forests">Lesser Sundas deciduous forests</a> ecoregion.
The Tanimbar Islands, Kai Islands, and Barat Daya Islands (except for Wetar) in the southeastern Banda Sea form the <a href="Banda%20Sea%20Islands%20moist%20deciduous%20forests">Banda Sea Islands moist deciduous forests</a> <a href="ecoregion">ecoregion</a>. These islands are covered in mostly-intact rain forest, and home to a number of <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> plants and animals including twenty-one bird species, a very high number for this small ecoregion. There are only twenty-two native mammals on these islands, including the rare <a href="dusky%20pademelon">dusky pademelon</a> "(Thylogale brunii)" and <a href="Indonesian%20tomb%20bat">Indonesian tomb bat</a> ("Taphozous achates"), and the endangered <a href="endemism">endemic</a> <a href="Kei%20myotis">Kei myotis</a> bat "(Myotis stalkeri)". The birdlife is threatened by egg collectors and even more by cats and rodents that have been introduced to the islands. <a href="Yamdena">Yamdena</a> in the Tanimbar Islands is an example of a large and fairly unspoilt habitat and is a protected area. The base for visiting these islands is by plane or ship from <a href="Ambon%20Island">Ambon Island</a> to the north. The Banda and Kai Islands, although remote, are visited by tourists for snorkelling and for their unspoilt beaches. Various cetacean species have been recorded including either or both <a href="blue%20whale">blue</a> and <a href="pygmy%20blue%20whale">pygmy blue whale</a>s and <a href="Omura%27s%20whale">Omura's whale</a>s.
